name: polygon
title: Polygon Mask
description: Used to train object detection, semantic segmentation, and instance segmentation. Masks in Darwin can be pixel-wise or coarse but remain vectorized, keeping annotation files light. Masks are the swiss army knife of vision AI, and can be converted into almost every other type of annotation.
cons: Non-visual objects, such as a midpoint or curvature

name: mask
title: Raster Mask
description: Used to train semantic and panoptic segmentation models.
cons: Non-visual objects, such as a midpoint or curvature

name: bounding_box
title: Bounding Box
description: Used to train detectors. Bounding boxes are not as precise as polygon masks, but in some cases cheaper to compute. In Darwin, masks can be converted to bounding boxes but not the other way around.
cons: Composite objects, or frequently occluded objects

name: keypoint
title: Keypoint
description: Defines a point that may represent an object or marker. Keypoints can be used alone, or in combination to form a point map that defines the pose of an object.
pros: Object markers, such as face points or corners
Non-visual objects, such as the inner midpoint of an object
cons: Markers that vary greatly in scale

name: tag
title: Tag
description: Tags describe a whole image for classification purposes. Unlike other annotations, they don’t apply to an area in particular, and should be used to describe features visible throughout an image, or define an image category.
pros: Objects taking up 50% or more than an image
Visual features that are present, but not positional, such as "over-exposed"
cons: Identifying small objects, or objects in scenes
Identifying multiple objects, counting, or any positional logic

name: cuboid
title: Cuboid
description: Used for 3D and 6 degree-of-freedom object detectors. Cuboids are 3-dimensional bounding boxes that can enclose an item, defining its dimension and pose in a captured scene.
pros: Objects on flat planes that need to be navigated, such as cars

name: skeleton
title: Keypoint Skeleton
description: A network of keypoints connected by vectors. Used to define the 2D or 3D pose of a multi-limbed object. Keypoints skeletons have a defined set of points that can be moved to adapt to an object’s appearance.
pros: Objects with a defined number of marker points
cons: Objects with an undefined number of joints, such as a tree

name: instance_id
title: Instance ID
description: Instance IDs, also knowns as object or tracking IDs, allow you to re-identify a specific object throughout a dataset. Each annotation is given a numeric ID so that the object may be tracked, or simply distinguished among other objects of the same class in an image. Darwin isolates all annotations in instances by default, however adding an Instance ID allows you to preserve and re-use this ID between images.

name: attributes
title: Attributes
description: A tag on an annotation. Attributes describe objects in greater detail than the class name itself. They can define discrete features like color, or continuous ones like age. Attributes help AI classify objects after detecting them.
pros: Any object with relevant variable traits
features: Any model that can support an attribute defining head.

name: auto_annotate
title: Keypoint Skeleton
description: A network of keypoints connected by vectors. Used to define the 2D or 3D pose of a multi-limbed object. Keypoints skeletons have a defined set of points that can be moved to adapt to an object’s appearance.
pros: Objects with a defined number of marker points
cons: Objects with an undefined number of joints, such as a tree

name: text
title: Text
description: Apply free text to an annotation. Text can be used to train OCR, or to include unique textual information about an annotation. Unlike attributes, text isn’t saved to be re-applied to other annotations.
pros: Entering freeform text, such as in clinical notes or transcribed text

name: line
title: Line
description: A series of points forming a line. Line, or polyline annotations, may be used to define a slope, direction, or edge. They are often used to define lane markings or trajectories.
pros: Linearly defined objects with no volume, such as edges
Non-visual objects such as mid-points or trajectories

name: directional_vector
title: Directional Vector
description: Defines a radian value of the vendor to indicate the 2D pose or direction of an object. These vectors can be used to predict movement, or define an object’s tilt.
pros: Solid objects with a relevant direction or pose
cons: Objects with more than 4 degrees of freedom of movement

name: ellipse
title: Ellipse
description: An oval that appears as a 2-diameter circle or multi-point polygon on export. Can be used as a round polygon, or as an ellipse to mark circular objects that may distort with perspective.
pros: Items that can be regressed with 2-3 values (diameters, centroid)
cons: Polygonal objects that aren't round or oval.

name: link
title: Link
description: A link between two annotations of any type.
pros: Items that share any kind of structured relationship
cons: Items that are not consistently related
